aws::graph::propositions: # Civil Air Patrol Aircraft Hard Landing Incident in Marion, South Carolina
Cessna 182T aircraft was involved in a hard landing incident.
The incident occurred on September 7, 2012, at 08:10 Local time.
The incident occurred in Marion, South Carolina.
The aircraft registration was N635CP.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
Two people were aboard the aircraft.
No injuries were reported in the incident.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Other work use.
The aircraft was being used for a Civil Air Patrol mission.
The Civil Air Patrol mission was assigned by the U.S. Air Force.
The pilot flying was a flight instructor seated in the left seat.
The pilot-not-flying was a private pilot seated in the right seat.
The flight instructor turned over the controls to the private pilot.
The private pilot performed a normal landing initially.
The private pilot took off to practice a short-field landing.
Both pilots reported the airplane touched down "firm" on the main landing gear.
As the airplane decelerated, it felt as if the airplane had a flat tire.
The propeller began to strike the runway shortly after touchdown.
A postaccident examination revealed damage to the nose landing gear attachment assembly.
A postaccident examination revealed substantial damage to the firewall.
Neither pilot could recall the airspeed during the approach.
Neither pilot could recall the flap configuration during the approach.
The flight instructor described the landing flare as a "momentary or short flare."
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of this accident to be the pilot's improper landing flare.
The improper landing flare resulted in a hard landing.
The National Transportation Safety Board identified "Aircraft control - Pilot" as a personnel issue in their findings.
The National Transportation Safety Board identified "Landing flare - Incorrect use/operation" as an aircraft issue in their findings.
The accident number assigned was ERA12CA553.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Marion, South Carolina

## Date & Time: 
September 7, 2012, 08:10 Local

## Aircraft:
Cessna 182T

## Defining Event:
Hard landing

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Other work use

## Accident Number:
ERA12CA553

## Registration:
N635CP

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
2 None

## Analysis

As the airplane arrived in the area of the destination airport, where the pilots would commence a Civil Air Patrol, U.S Air Force-assigned mission, the pilot flying (a flight instructor in the left seat) asked the pilot-not-flying (a private pilot in the right seat) if he wanted to practice takeoffs and landings. The flight instructor turned over the controls to the private pilot, and he performed a normal landing. The private pilot then took off to practice a short-field landing. Both pilots reported the airplane touched down "firm" on the main landing gear, and as the airplane decelerated, it felt as if the airplane had a flat tire. Shortly after, the propeller began to strike the runway. A postaccident examination of the airplane revealed damage to the nose landing gear attachment assembly and substantial damage to the firewall. During postaccident interviews, neither pilot could recall the airspeed during the approach or the flap configuration. The flight instructor described the landing flare as a "momentary or short flare."

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:
The pilot's improper landing flare, which resulted in a hard landing.

## Findings

| Aircraft | Landing flare - Incorrect use/operation |
| --- | --- |
| Personnel issues | Aircraft control - Pilot |

---
